abstract: This method is used to evaluate whether engineered fish passage structures meet specific criteria to ensure fish can continue to pass through for at least five years. The natural stream channel serves as a benchmark for fish migration. The closer a crossing structure deviates from the natural condition, the more difficult it becomes for fish to pass. Design criteria for new crossings and fish passage restoration are provided by Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) in their Water Crossing Design Guidelines. Evaluations will use data from Fish Passage Barrier and Surface Water Diversion Screen Assessment and Prioritization. Deviations of more than 20% from original design criteria are considered out of compliance. Projects built to these guidelines are presumed to provide fish passage, so monitoring upon completion and over time is essential for effectiveness assessment. For partial barriers, adult and juevnile fish densities must be evaluated to determine if fish utilization has improved. This method ensures compliance with best available science related to fish passage and addresses the issue of impaired fish passage in engineered structures.

description:
This text describes a methodology for evaluating the effectiveness of engineered fish passage structures post-construction, with a focus on determining whether they comply with design criteria and continue to provide fish passage for at least five years. The natural stream channel serves as a benchmark for comparing fish passage capabilities. Deviations from prevailing natural conditions can result in impaired fish passage.

The methodology utilizes design criteria outlined in the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) Water Crossing Design Guidelines (Barnard et al., 2013). These guidelines are based on current scientific knowledge related to fish passage. Data for evaluating fish passage structures will be derived from the Fish Passage Barrier and Surface Water Diversion Screen Assessment and Prioritization document published by WDFW in 2009.

Additionally, the gradient of the fish passage structure is measured and compared to the original design criteria. Deviations greater than 20% are considered out of compliance.

Projects designed and constructed according to the aforementioned guidance documents are assumed to provide fish passage. Monitoring of project design upon completion of construction and over time serves as an appropriate and measurable effectiveness monitoring method.

Evaluating partial fish passage barriers requires assessing adult and juvenile fish densities to determine if increased fish utilization has been achieved.
